refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: The cmdsynopsis element is used to model the syntax of command line interfaces. Broadly, a command line interface consists of a command followed by a variety of options. These options can be optional or required and may or may not be repeatable.

User expections about how these should be formatted vary by platform and publisher. The $v:arg-… variables are designed to make it easy to adapt to many common forms of presentation. Each contains (usually) a single character used as a delimiter:

Each of the default characters is placed in an HTML span with the class “cmdpunct”.

refsection.para: The bridgehead element allows the author to insert a heading without regard to the logical structure of the document. This variable controls how the values provided in the renderas attribute map to HTML. If there is no mapping for the specified rendering, it is rendered as a div.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Footnotes are generally numbered (or otherwise marked, see footnote-numeration) sequentially throughout a document. If the document is being broken into chunks, it may seem odd if the only footnote in a chunk is labeled “5”. If v:chunk-renumber-footnotes is true, the stylesheets will attempt to renumber footnotes in each chunk so that they begin at the first mark in each chunk.

refsection.para: This is an internal error. It indicates that the syntax of a dynamic profiling expression was unrecognized. Since dynamic profiling should only be applied to expressions that have been recognized, this error should never happen.

refsection.para: This is an internal error that should never happen. It indicates that stylesheet processing of footnotes during “chunking” has gone awry. If you see this error, please file an issue for it.

refsection.para: All of the variables that can be used in dynamic profiling (see ) must be in this map. The default value of this map includes all of the (dynamic) DocBook stylesheet parameters. If you add new parameters in a customization layer and you want to be able to use those values in dynamic profiling, you must update this variable.

refsection.para: This variable, usually derived from formal-object-title-placement is a map from element (local) names to placements. The placement is either “before” or “after”.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: If the highlight.js syntax highlighter is selected (see verbatim-syntax-highlighter), these elements are added to the head element to load and configure the highlighter.
Starting with the DocBook xslTNG Stylesheets version 1.4.1, any link elements will be added to the head element before links to user-defined CSS files so that property overrides may be specified.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: If the extension functions necessary to determine the intrinsic height of an image are unavailable, or if the height cannot be determined, this value will be used as the assumed intrinsic height of the image. This is generally the parsed value of image-nominal-height.

refsection.para: If the extension functions necessary to determine the intrinsic width of an image are unavailable, or if the width cannot be determined, this value will be used as the assumed intrinsic width of the image. This is generally the parsed value of image-nominal-width.

refnamediv.refpurpose: A list of characters that are invisible in verbatim environments

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: When callouts are being inserted into a verbatim environment, the stylesheets must count the characters in each line in order to find the correct column. The characters in this list are considered invisible and do not increase the column count as they’re passed.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Base URI of images and other media in the XML sources

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This value is calculated from the mediaobject-input-base-uri parameter. If the parameter is the empty string, then this value is the empty sequence. Otherwise, this value is the absolute URI that results from resolving the value of the mediaobject-input-base-uri parameter against the static base URI of the stylesheet.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Base URI of images and other media in the output

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This value is calculated from the mediaobject-output-base-uri parameter. If the parameter is the empty string, then this value is the empty sequence. Otherwise, this value is the value of the mediaobject-output-base-uri parameter, which is assumed to be absolute. A trailing slash will be added to the parameter value if it is not present.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: To calculate the width of the columns in some complex CALS tables, the stylesheets need to know the page width. The nominal-page-width is used for this value. It is generally the value of nominal-page-width parsed as a length (see ).

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: The v:olink-databases variable is usually derived from the olink-databases parameter. It must contain a sequence of olink target databases.

refnamediv.refpurpose: The list of known personal name styles

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: The stylesheets can format personal names in a variety of ways. This variable contains the list of known ways, see t:person-name.

refnamediv.refpurpose: CSS and JavaScript to support Prism

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: If the prism syntax highlighter is selected (see verbatim-syntax-highlighter), these elements are added to the head element to load and configure the highlighter.
Starting with the DocBook xslTNG Stylesheets version 1.4.1, any link elements will be added to the head element before links to user-defined CSS files so that property overrides may be specified.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para:
The stylesheets use templates, as described in , to determine the formatting of title pages
The term “title pages” should be understood very broadly here. Anything that has a title has a title page, even if that “page” consists of only a single heading.. Any templates provided in v:templates will be used preferentially to whatever builtin templates exist.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This variable is part of the experimental themes feature. It enumerates the available themes. Each theme has three parts, a name, an ID, and (optionally) an indication of whether or not it’s a “dark” theme.
Themes are implemented in CSS. If the theme-picker is enabled, it will be possible for the reader to select a theme. The theme names are used for this purpose.
The ID value is used as a class on the html element. Everything else about the theme is implemented in CSS. To add a new theme, provide a set of CSS rules that apply when the ID class is in effect.

The dark mode setting is only used as a default. If the document does not specify a default-theme, if the user has never selected a theme, if the user has enabled dark mode at the operating system level, and if the browser makes this fact available, the first “dark” theme will automatically be selected.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Titles are complicated. They occur all over the place (on books, on chapters, on sections, on figures, on formal paragraphs, etc.) and they need to be rendered differently in different contexts. You are always free to write your own templates to completely customize the formatting, but the stylesheets provide five declarative properties that you can select for each title. As long as your formatting requirements are satisfied by these properties, you don’t have two write custom templates to do the formatting.
The properties are label, number, number format, inherit, and “label-toc”. Consider the title in .

mediaobject.alt: Illustration of title properties in a section title.

textobject.para: This image shows the title “Section 3.4 Changing the print head” identifying “Section” as the label, “3.4” as the number, and “3.” as the inherited number.

refsection.para: For any title context, identified by an XPath expression, you can set the label and number properties to specify whether or not those elements should appear. If inherit is true, the number of the parent element is included (so the figure might be section 4 in chapter 3, for example). The number-format property determines what style of numeration is used (arabic, lower- or upper-alpha, or lower- or upper-roman, for example).

The last property, label-toc, determines whether or not the label appears in the table of contents. This can be used, for example, to suppress the label “Figure” at the beginning of every figure in a list of figures.

The stylesheets search this list sequentially and the first match is used. Observe that v:user-title-properties always comes first; if you want to override the default values, you can put your overrides in there. You do not have to redefine the entire list.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Title pages, taken loosely to mean anything with a title, are formatted using templates, see . If a template doesn’t exist for a particular context, the v:titlepage-default template is used.

refsection.title: Description

refsection.para: The v:unit-scale map contains a set of measurement units and their absolute length in terms of pixels (as computed with pixels-per-inch).
Recognized units at the time of this writing are shown in .

refnamediv.refpurpose: A list determining how callouts are processed

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This value is a sequence constructed automatically from the verbatim-callouts parameter.

refnamediv.refpurpose: List of verbatim elements to be rendered in the line style

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: The elements whose local names appear in this list will be formatted using the line verbatim style by default. For a discussion of verbatim elements and styles, see .
This list is usually constructed from the verbatim-line-style parameter.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: When formatting verbatim environments with line numbers, every verbatim-number-every-nth line is numbered.
This value is usually constructed from the verbatim-number-every-nth parameter.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Always number the first line of a verbatim listing?

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: When formatting verbatim environments with line numbers, the first line will be numbered (irrespective of the setting of v:verbatim-number-every-nth if this value is true.
This value is usually constructed from the verbatim-number-first-line parameter.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: When formatting verbatim environments with line numbers, environments less than verbatim-number-minlines in length will not be numbered.
This value is usually constructed from the verbatim-number-minlines parameter.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Identifies verbatim elements that should have line numbers

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: A list of the verbatim environments that should be numbered.
This value is usually constructed from the verbatim-numbered-elements parameter.

refnamediv.refpurpose: List of verbatim elements to be rendered in the plain style

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: The elements whose local names appear in this list will be formatted using the plain verbatim style by default. For a discussion of verbatim elements and styles, see .
This list is usually constructed from the verbatim-plain-style parameter.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Controls the verbatim properties of an element

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: When processing a verbatim environment, this array of maps is consulted to determine what properties apply to the verbatim environment. Most simple, global customizations of verbatim environments can be achieved by setting the verbatim-line-style, verbatim-plain-style, verbatim-callouts, and verbatim-numbered-elements parameters.

refnamediv.refpurpose: The space character to use when padding verbatim lines

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: When a verbatim line has to be padded in order to get a callout to appear in the correct column, this character will be used as the padding character. For a discussion of verbatim elements and styles, see .
This character is usually constructed from the verbatim-space parameter. Unlike the verbatim-space, this variable must be a node not a string.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Languages for which syntax highlighting should be performed

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: The verbatim-syntax-highlight-languages is a single string for the convenience of users. This variable contains the languages as a list.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: If the Pygments Pygments Syntax highlightingPygments syntax highlighter is applied, the verbatim-syntax-highlight-options are applied.
Three options are recognized:

listitem.para: The programming language to use for syntax highlighting. This option is required.
If the show-command option is true (“1”, “yes”, or “true”), then the pygmentize command will be printed. This is a debugging option.
If the show-result option is true (“1”, “yes”, or “true”), then the string returned from pygmentize will be printed. This is a debugging option.

note.para: Syntax highlighting with Pygments requires spawning an external process for each highlighted environment. This can add significantly to the processing time if there are many such environments.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: If the Pygments Pygments Syntax highlightingPygments syntax highlighter is applied, the verbatim-syntax-highlight-pygments-options are applied.
Each key/value pair in the map will be passed to pygmentize as a -Pkey=value option.

refnamediv.refpurpose: List of verbatim elements to be rendered in the table style

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: The elements whose local names appear in this list will be formatted using the line verbatim style by default. For a discussion of verbatim elements and styles, see .
This list is usually constructed from the verbatim-table-style parameter.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This variable holds the version number of the stylesheets.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Generally speaking the VERSION is sufficient to identify the stylesheets. The VERSION-ID adds a unique identifier derived from the latest git commit.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Cross-references, like title properties, are complicated. They can occur almost anywhere and several styles are possible.

textobject.para: This image shows the cross-reference “Section 3.4, Changing the print head” identifying “Section” as the label, “3.4” as the number, and “, ” as number separator and “Changing the print head” as the title.

refsection.para: For documents with numbered sections, a style such as the one shown in is common. Here the label, number, and title are sufficient.

mediaobject.alt: Illustration of cross-reference properties in an unnumbered section reference

textobject.para: This image shows the title “Section 3.4 Changing the print head” identifying “Section” as the label, “3.4” as the number, and “3.” as the inherited number.

refsection.para: For documents without section numbers, a different approach is required. In , we see how a prefix (which can be literal text or a key into a localization) precedes the title. If an inherit reference is defined, the cross reference will include a reference to that element as well. A separator can be placed between them. If the format for the inherited reference also specifies an inherited reference, the process will continue.
